content.description: This route branches off of the rightward-traversing line of bolts leading from the start of Bill and Tee's. Shares anchors with Corporal Punishment.
content.location: First route to the right of Corporal Punishment.

content.description: An odd route that definitely "strays" from the bolt line. The beginning is intentionally bolted to force a face move that is probably the crux of the climb but then the climb moves into the chimney for 2 bolts. Up higher there is a great looking, thin section of wall that is appealing but the path of least resistance climbs the dirty rock to the left.
content.location: left side of gully (nice cool breeze) 30 feet left of Group Therapy. Last route on Applejack Wall in Yusuf's guide.

climbs.name: Stalking Horse
climbs.fa: Equipped by Chris Schmick, FA Brian Capps 2019

content.description: A great looking almost blank face that have never been sent. Good Luck
content.location: First sport route left of The Shootist

content.description: The start of this route can be accessed by aiding to the third bolt of Stalking Horse and reaching out right to clip into the belay anchors. If you’re going to be belayed from the ground, you'll need a 50m rope to get back down.A large runout protects the anchors which are located at the very top of the cliff. It may be a good idea to rappel in to evaluate the top of the climb before committing.
content.location: This is the first bolted route you will find left of Applejack Crack

content.description: A thought provoking and challenging climb for the grade on sculpted holds.  Don't let the top fool you!
content.location: to the right of extinguisher, just in front of elm tree
Found in between “Areteouffee” on the left, and “ Manhattan Project” on the right.

content.description: Beginning off the small boulder, pull through some tricky moves and the climbing get easier the higher you climb.
content.location: To the right of Ridin' Cowgirls.

content.description: Begins with a difficult boulder problem, which leads to hard sustained climbing and a blockbuster finish to the chains. To get full points for this route, avoid using the wall on the right. Contrived, I know.
content.location: This route is found between “Rajun’ Cajun” on the left, and “Buckets of Jam” on the right.

content.description: Climb using small crips to reach the top.
content.location: The short face just right of the small boulder

content.description: Cut left after the 5th bolt of Extinguisher to a 2 bolt extension and separate set of anchors. Often overlooked, but well worth the time if you don’t want the pocket pulling to end quite so soon.Note: as of 2021 there is a bolt about a foot up and left of the last bolt before the anchors with disintegrating red tape on it. Not sure if this was left with the intention to be removed, but in case the tape comes off use the lower right of the last 2 bolts.

100 feet left of Ragin' Cajun, stay inside broken block hallway. Starts in a roof with a large, flat flake. 5 QD to the first fixed anchor. Variation 5.13a. Two more QD left to the other fixed anchor. F/A Chris Schmick 2001 From "Vertical Heartland" 3rd edition by Eric Ulner
content.location: Dirt trail leading up to the wall takes you directly to the start of the climb.

content.description: This route can either be done by reaching around the corner from Bill and Tees and clipping the first bolt, or by starting all the way on the ground and clipping the first of a traversing line of bolts that lead to the starts of the next few routes to the right. (Surely this will make more sense when seen in person).This route is fully bolted and does not require gear.
content.protection: 7 or 8 bolts, depending on where you start.
content.location: Right and around the arete from Bill & Tee's Excellent Adventure

content.description:
A bouldery start will get you onto the plates that  line the face, but you're not out of the bucket yet. Alternate jug hauling the face and thrutching in the wide crack until you come out to the ledge, where you can take a seat and consider your next move.  

  The anchor/descent is not ideal. You could scramble up the gully and try to find a tree to belay from, but I'm not sure what is available and getting down will be more of a chore. You can also traverse the ledge to the shiny new anchors two routes over and belay from there, but your follower might not be thrilled about the traverse. 

  Awkward route, but buckets of fun if you're into that kind of thing.
content.protection: Standard rack, big stuff is probably a good idea.
content.location: Large dihedral crack on the big ledge.

content.description: Climb up the arete to the right.
content.protection: 5 bolts. It’s advised to stick clip the first bolt:
content.location: Found in between “Buckets of Jam” on the left and “Corporal Punishment” on the right.

content.description: Climb up to the depression near bolt 3. Be ready for hard moves
content.location: First spot route to the right of Applejack Crack
Found in between “Ain’t No Sunshine” on the left, and “Rajun’ Cajun” on the right.

content.description: From behind the large tree, follow the thin crack upward until it widens into a large water groove off width/chimney at about 15 feet. Follow to the top.
content.protection: Trad gear - large sizes and thin stuff for the beginning (I used micro-wires)
content.location: Just to the left of the end of The Gallery, just past the large chimney/gully.

content.description: Difficult moves off of thin holds, monos, and bad slopers on great stone = one difficult route!
content.location: Found in between “Ice Harvest” on the left, and “Areteouffee” on the right.

content.description: Just past Group Therapy, Applejack Wall covers from just before Applejack Crack up to Rajun Cajun and also included in this section are the newly developed routes from Rajun Cajun, down to the west falls.
